channel.title: Bobby Jack’s Switch reviews
channel.description: Nintendo Switch reviews written by Bobby Jack

item.title: The Flame in the Flood
item.description: An absorbing game which represents value for money, marred by bugs and flawed mechanics

item.title: SteamWorld Dig 2
item.description: A joy to play and a perfect introduction to the metroidvania genre

item.title: Dig Dog
item.description: Dig Dog is a fast-paced, perfectly-pitched rogue-lite, offering an addictive slice of nostalgia

item.title: Golf Story
item.description: A quirky combination of sports game and RPG produces a highly original and entertaining result

item.title: Ding Dong XL
item.description: Ding Dong XL couldn’t be simpler, so it’s hard to love, but easy to enjoy

item.title: The Way Remastered
item.description: The Way Remastered has some problems, but it pays homage to a certain style of challenging action platformer very well indeed

item.title: Gato Roboto
item.description: Gato Roboto is adorable, and ideally suited to nostalgic handheld play, but — cute graphics aside — fails to be really memorable

item.title: Kid Tripp
item.description: Despite an aversion for auto-runners, I found Kid Tripp enjoyable, if on the short side.

item.title: Celeste
item.description: Celeste answers the question ‘how can you make a plot really work in a video game?’. It’s a question we should all be asking more often, particularly when this is the answer.

item.title: Box Align
item.description: Box align is a 3d game stuck in a 2d world. Its core mechanic suffers as a result, and it doesn’t have enough redeeming features to make up for it.

item.title: Baba Is You
item.description: Baba is game. Mechanics are modifiable. Game is fun and challenging.

item.title: Super Box Land Demake
item.description: This great-looking Sokoban-like has some excellent levels, but too few of them

item.title: Yoku’s Island Express
item.description: Yoku’s Island Express is a bewitching combination of arcade pinball mechanics and enchanting metroidvania. But is it more than the sum of its parts, or does the gimmick result in a game which falls short of the two genres’ potential?

item.title: Animal Crossing: New Horizons
item.description: Animal Crossing is compelling and frustrating, a modern day doll’s house with too little to do, that will probably still have you coming back time and time again.

item.title: The Adventures of Elena Temple
item.description: A game steeped in nostalgia that will delight old-timers but frustrate modern gamers.

item.title: Pixboy
item.description: A retro platformer with enough modern touches to make it wonderfully playable.

item.title: Spiritfarer
item.description: Spiritfarer is a captivating game with exploration, crafting, and platforming elements, woven around the moving stories of its characters.

item.title: Ministry of Broadcast
item.description: Big Brother meets … Big Brother. In this pixellated tale of dystopian reality game show, you’re tasked with completing a series of platforming puzzles — by fair means or foul.

item.title: Xeodrifter
item.description: This Metroidvania is minimal in every way, but manages to deliver a great gameplay experience by focussing on the essentials.

item.title: Yooka-Laylee and the Impossible Lair
item.description: This 2D platformer has bags of flexibility and variety, with great level design, although its gimmicks don’t hit home 100% of the time.
